body_content.explanation: immediately after the first and before any others:
examples: Is Carla her first or second child?
This is the second time I've had flu this winter.
Today is the second (of March).

body_content.explanation: the position in which a person finishes a race or competition if they finish immediately behind the winner:
examples: First prize is two weeks in Barbados and second prize is a weekend in Rome.
Jones took second place in the long jump.

body_content.explanation: Second is used to show that only one thing is better, bigger, etc. than the thing mentioned:
examples: St Petersburg is Russia's second (biggest/largest) city.
Iraq's oil reserves are second only to Saudi Arabia's.

body_content.explanation: another:
examples: She is often described as a second Marilyn Monroe.
You really should make the most of the opportunity, because you won't get a second chance.
Richard and Liz have a second home in the mountains.
Pay attention to what she's saying because she won't explain it a second time.

body_content.explanation: happening only once out of every two possible times:
examples: We've decided to hold the conference every second year.

body_content.explanation: in a group of musicians or singers, relating to the lower of two instruments, voices, or parts:
examples: She sings second soprano in the school choir.
I started as second trumpet, and I'm still second trumpet.

body_content.explanation: after the first and before any others:
examples: Robertson won the race and Cameron was/came/finished second.
In this business, money comes first and principles come a very poor second (= they are much less important).

body_content.explanation: used to introduce the second thing in a list of things you want to say or write:
examples: There are two good reasons why we can't do it. First, we can't afford it, and second, we don't have time.

body_content.explanation: a short unit of time that is equal to a 60th of a minute:
examples: There are 60 seconds in a minute.
These computers process millions of instructions per second.
The new system can trace a phone call in a fraction of a second.

body_content.explanation: a very short period of time:
examples: "Come on, hurry up!" "I'll just/only be a second - I need to close the window."
Do you have a second, Paul? I need to talk to you.
It won't take a second (= it will be very quick).
Wait a couple of/a few seconds before trying again.

body_content.explanation: as soon as :
examples: The second I saw him, I knew he was going to be a star.

body_content.explanation: the second person or thing to do or be something, or the second person or thing mentioned:
examples: This is the second of the four tests.

body_content.explanation: an extra amount of food that is given after the first amount has been eaten:
examples: Would anyone like seconds of ice cream?

body_content.explanation: the smallest unit used for measuring an angle:
examples: There are 3,600 seconds in a degree.

body_content.explanation: a product that is sold cheaply because it is damaged or not in perfect condition
a person who takes care of someone who is fighting in a boxing competition or, in the past, in a duel (= organized fight):
examples: At the end of the fight he had to be helped out of the ring by his seconds.

body_content.explanation: in a vehicle, the gear that combines power with limited speed and is used when increasing or reducing speed:
examples: You'll have to change (down/up) into second.

body_content.explanation: an undergraduate degree from a university in the UK and some other countries that is a good degree but not the best possible

another word for 
second base :
examples: Garcia reached second on a throwing error.
He is an equally good fielder at second and shortstop.

body_content.explanation: In a group of musicians or singers, a second is a person who plays or sings the lower of two parts:
examples: The first violins were seated on the left side of the stage, opposite the seconds.
She's usually a second but today she's singing first.

body_content.explanation: the distance between two musical notes that are two notes apart:
examples: a major/minor second
Here, the brass and woodwinds play minor seconds to represent bleating sheep.

body_content.explanation: to make a formal statement of support for a suggestion made by someone else during a meeting so that there can be a discussion or vote:
examples: The motion was proposed by the club's chairwoman and seconded by the secretary.
"I could use a drink." "I'll second that (= I agree with you)!"

body_content.explanation: to send an employee to work somewhere else temporarily, either to increase the number of workers or to replace other workers, or to exchange experience or skills:
examples: During the dispute, many police officers were seconded from traffic duty to the prison service.
